story.title: Why was AnkaPulse born?
story.p1: As developers, we know what it's like to work on a personal project, an MVP for a startup, or as a freelancer and need professional monitoring tools without breaking the bank.
story.p2Bold: existing platforms are designed for companies with budgets of thousands of dollars per month.
story.p2After: Their dashboards are full of features you'll never use, their plans are prohibitive for indie developers and early-stage startups, and the complexity wastes your time instead of saving it.
story.p3Bold: we believe every developer deserves professional tools without breaking their budget.
story.p4After: "Anka" is a Quechua word meaning "eagle" - a bird that flies high and has a panoramic view of everything below. Combined with "Pulse," it represents our mission:
story.p4Mission: to be the eyes that monitor your services' pulse from above,
story.p4End: detecting any issues before they affect your users.

downtimeHistoryPage.title: The 5 Most Expensive Downtime Cases in History
downtimeHistoryPage.subtitle: When downtime doesn't cost thousands, but millions of dollars

intro.p1: When we think about downtime, we usually think of lost minutes, some frustrated users, maybe a couple of sales that didn't close. Annoying, yes. Costly, too. But we rarely think about the true cost of downtime at scale.
intro.p2: Today I'll tell you about 5 real cases where downtime didn't cost hundreds or thousands of dollars. It cost millions. In some cases, hundreds of millions. And in the most extreme case, it almost destroyed an entire company in less than an hour.
intro.p3: These stories aren't just to learn from others' mistakes. They're reminders that in the digital world,
intro.p3End: . And that the cost of not being prepared can be devastating.

amazon.title: Amazon Prime Day 2018: $100 Million in 63 Minutes

story.title: The Story
story.p1: It was July 2018. Amazon had been promoting its Prime Day for weeks. Millions of users ready to buy. Massive discounts. The biggest sales event of the year.

timeline.start: 11:00 AM PT: Prime Day officially begins

story.p2: For 63 minutes, users around the world saw the same thing: an image of a dog with the message "Uh oh! Something went wrong on our end."
story.problemDesc: Amazon's servers couldn't handle the massive traffic they themselves had generated with their marketing.

numbers.title: The Numbers
numbers.perMinute: Amazon lost approximately $1.6 million per minute

lesson.title: The Lesson
lesson.p1: Amazon is literally one of the most technologically advanced companies in the world. They have AWS. They have the best engineers. They have virtually unlimited resources.
lesson.p2: And yet, they underestimated their own traffic. The lesson:

items.1: Do load testing on your critical endpoints
items.5: Communicate proactively if there are problems

facebook.title: Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp (2021): 6 Hours That Cost $60 Million

story.title: The Story
story.p1: October 4, 2021. 11:40 AM ET. Suddenly, Facebook disappears from the internet.
story.p2: Not just the website. Not just the app. The entire company. Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp, Oculus. Everything offline. For 6 hours.
story.problemDesc: A BGP (Border Gateway Protocol) configuration error made Facebook's servers "deleted" from the internet. For the global internet, Facebook ceased to exist.
story.worstDesc: Engineers couldn't access the buildings because access cards were also connected to internal systems. They had to physically cut locks to enter the data centers.

numbers.title: The Numbers
numbers.zuck: Zuckerberg lost $6 billion in stock that day

lesson.title: The Lesson
lesson.p1: The error wasn't in the code. It wasn't a bug. It wasn't an attack. It was an infrastructure configuration error during a routine update.
lesson.conclusionDesc: The most dangerous errors aren't the obvious ones. They're the ones that happen in critical systems during "routine maintenance".

britishAirways.title: British Airways (2017): $100 Million from an Electricity Problem

story.title: The Story
story.p1: May 27, 2017. Long weekend in the UK. Thousands of families ready to travel.
story.p2: A contractor at British Airways' data center accidentally disconnects the power supply. When reconnecting it, the power surge damages critical systems.
story.resultDesc: Absolute chaos. British Airways had to cancel 726 flights over 3 days. 75,000 passengers stranded at airports worldwide.

lesson.title: The Lesson
lesson.p1: British Airways had outsourced their IT to "reduce costs". In the process, they eliminated critical redundancies.
lesson.p2: They saved millions on IT. It cost them hundreds of millions when it failed.
lesson.conclusion: Disaster recovery isn't an expense, it's insurance.

delta.title: Delta Airlines (2016): 5 Hours of Chaos from a Failed Switchover

story.title: The Story
story.p1: August 8, 2016, 2:30 AM. An electrical problem at Delta's main data center in Atlanta.
story.p2: The automatic switchover to the backup system...
story.p2End: . Critical systems shut down. Check-in, boarding, crew scheduling, everything offline.
story.p3: Delta had to cancel 2,300 flights over 3 days. The CEO had to apologize publicly.

lesson.title: The Key Lesson
lesson.p1: Delta HAD backup systems. Delta HAD redundancy. Delta HAD invested in disaster recovery.
lesson.p2: But they never properly tested the switchover.
lesson.p2End: When they really needed it, it didn't work. A disaster recovery plan that isn't tested is a disaster recovery plan that doesn't exist.

knight.title: Knight Capital (2012): $440 Million Lost in 45 Minutes

story.title: The Wildest Story of All
story.p1: August 1, 2012, 9:30 AM. Knight Capital, a trading firm, deploys new software to production.
story.problemDesc: The new code accidentally reactivates an old function that had been deprecated 8 years earlier. This function starts executing trades automatically. Thousands. Millions.
story.p2: In 45 minutes, the software executes buy and sell orders worth $7 billion.
story.p3: By the time they realize and shut down the systems, Knight Capital had accumulated $440 million in losses.

numbers.title: The Devastating Numbers
numbers.consequence: Consequence: The company nearly went bankrupt
numbers.perMinute: Knight Capital lost $9.7 million per minute

lesson.title: The Unique Lesson
lesson.p1: This case is unique because it wasn't traditional downtime. The system worked "perfectly". The problem was it was doing exactly what it SHOULDN'T do.
lesson.conclusionDesc: Deployment errors can be catastrophic. The code you deploy can destroy your company in minutes.

pattern.title: The Common Pattern in All These Cases
pattern.intro: Looking at these 5 cases, there's a pattern that repeats:

items.4: None thought it would happen to them
items.5: The problem wasn't lack of resources

pattern.goodNews: The good news: None of these problems were inevitable.

appliedLessons.title: What We Can Learn (Applied to Real Projects)

notAmazon.title: "But I'm not Amazon or Facebook"
notAmazon.p1: True. You don't have their scale. But you have the same risks, proportionally.
notAmazon.p2: If your SaaS bills $5,000/month and is down 6 hours, you don't lose $60 million. But you can lose users, reputation and revenue that took you months to build.

monitoring.title: Monitoring is not optional
monitoring.description: You don't need to spend thousands. But you need to KNOW when something fails. Before your users tell you.

backups.title: Backups without testing aren't backups
backups.description: Having a backup you've never tested is the same as not having a backup.

infrastructure.title: Infrastructure changes are dangerous
infrastructure.description: Treat every infrastructure change as if it could break everything. Because it can.

documentation.title: Document your procedures
documentation.description: When everything's on fire, you don't want to be googling "how to rollback".

automation.title: Automate carefully
automation.description: Automation is incredible. Until it does something it shouldn't, at scale.

deployment.title: NEVER deploy directly to production
deployment.description: Staging, testing, feature flags. Deployment is where most things can go wrong.

realCost.title: The Real Cost of Downtime
realCost.intro: These extreme cases show us something important: the cost of downtime isn't just the revenue lost during those minutes or hours.

items.1: Users who leave and don't return

comparison.amazon: For Amazon, $100 million is a bad day.
comparison.startup: For your startup, 6 hours of downtime can be the end.

conclusion.title: Conclusion
conclusion.intro: I'm not telling you these stories to scare you. I'm telling you so you understand that:

points.1: Downtime happens to everyone (even the giants)
points.3: Monitoring and backups aren't expenses, they're insurance
points.4: Learning from others is cheaper than making your own mistakes

conclusion.need: You don't need Amazon's infrastructure to apply these lessons. You need:

items.3: A plan for when things fail
items.4: The humility to know YOUR systems can also fail

final.main: It's not a question of IF it will happen. It's a question of WHEN.
final.sub: And how prepared you are when it does.
